facts.text: On December 11, 1947, the appellant granted to the Shivrajpur Syndicate Ltd. rights for mining manganese ore from lands in two villages, Shivrajpur and Bhat.

anchor.surface_text: On December 11, 1947, the appellant granted to the Shivrajpur Syndicate Ltd. rights for the mining manganese ore from lands in two villages, Shivrajpur and Bhat.

facts.text: The lease was for a term of twelve years deemed to commence from December 1, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: To hold the premises granted and demised unto the lessee for the term of twelve years which shall be deemed to have companymended from the first of December one thousand nine hundred and forty-five

facts.text: Syndicate agreed to pay Rs. 2,629-8-8 as rent and royalty at 8 per cent of the sale value of all manganese ore.

anchor.surface_text: By part V the syndicate agreed to pay Rs. 2,629-8-8 as rent and royalty at the rate of 8 per cent. of the sale value of all manganese ore.

facts.text: Clause 1 of part VII required lessee to pay rent, royalty, and all taxes, rates, assessments, impositions including local fund cess.

anchor.surface_text: By clause 1 of part VII it was agreed that The lessee shall pay the rent and royalty reserved by this lease at the time and in the manner provided in the Parts V and VI and shall also pay and discharge all taxes, rates, assessments and imposition whatsoever

facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 16,309 from syndicate in year ending July 31, 1951, and Rs. 39,515 in year ending July 31, 1952, as local fund cess, being 3/16th of rent and royalty.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant received from the syndicate, besides rents and royalty, Rs. 16,309 in the year ending July 31, 1951, and Rs. 39,515 in the year ending July 31, 1952, being 3/16th of the amount of rent and royalty payable

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Ward B, Panch Mahals, brought Rs.16,309 and Rs.39,515 to tax in assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer, Ward B, Panch Mahals, brought these two amounts to tax in the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54.

facts.text: In appeal to Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Baroda Range, appellant claimed sums not taxable as local fund cess collected on behalf of Government or Local Board, or casual non-recurring; AAC upheld and excluded from total income.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Baroda Range, it was maintained by the appellant that the to sums were number taxable, because they represented local fund cess companylected by him on behalf of the Government of Bombay or the Local Board, Panch Mahals, and in any event because they were receipts of a causal and number-recurring nature.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal held sums received under clause 1 part VII, not as local fund cess on behalf of government, not casual non-recurring.

anchor.surface_text: In the view of the Income-tax Appellant Tribunal, the appellant received the two sums from the syndicate under the clause 1 of part VII of the lease agreement and number as local fund cess on behalf of the Government of the Bombay or of the Local Board

facts.text: Tribunal submitted consolidated statement under section 66(2) to High Court of Bombay with two questions.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal submitted a companysolidated statement of the case under section 66 2  of the Income-tax Act in respect of the years of assessment and submitted the following questions for the opinion of the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Questions to HC: 1. Whether Rs.16,309/Rs.39,515 received by assessee from syndicate is income under Income-tax Act,1922? 2. If yes, exempt under s.4(3)(vii) as casual non-recurring?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sum of Rs. 16,309/Rs. 39,515 received by the assessee from the syndicate is income for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 192 ?  II  If the answer to the above question is in the affirmative, whether the income-receipt is exempt under section 4 3  vii  of the Act

facts.text: Lands ceased to be alienated villages between August 1, 1950, and August 15, 1950, due to Bombay Taluqdari Abolition Act, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: In companypliance with an order of the High Court, the Tribunal submitted a supplementary statement of the case observing that the lands in question which were alienated villages between August 1, 1950, and August 15, 1950, had ceased to be alienated villages

facts.text: Total assessment payable Rs.1,222.92, local fund cess Rs.270.45 nP., total Jama payable to appellant Rs.504.45 nP.; cess as % of land revenue not Jama.

anchor.surface_text: that the total amount of assessment payable in respect of these villages was Rs. 1,222.92 and the local fund cess due in respect of the lands was Rs. 270.45 nP., that the total Jama payable to the appellant was Rs. 504.45 nP.

facts.text: High Court answered first question affirmatively, subject to reservation that amount of cess legally liable under Bombay Local Boards Act not subject to income-tax; second question negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in the light of the supplementary statement of the case, recorded its answer on the first question in the affirmative, subject to the reservation that the amount of cess which the appellant was legally liable to pay under the Bombay Local Boards Act was number subject to income-tax

facts.text: Appeals preferred to Supreme Court with certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: With certificate granted by the High Court, these appeals have been preferred.

facts.text: Local fund cess payable for two villages was Rs.270.45 being 3/16ths of Rs.1,222.92 land revenue; but amounts paid by syndicate considerably exceeded.

anchor.surface_text: The local fund cess payable for the two villages demised by the appellant was, according to finding of the Tribunals, Rs. 270.45 being 3/16ths of Rs. 1,222.92 the amount of land revenue assessed on the lands. But the amounts paid by the syndicate

facts.text: Syndicate believed liable to pay cess at 3 annas per rupee of rent and royalty.

anchor.surface_text: The syndicate believed that it was liable to pay to the appellant under clause 1 of the Part VII of the indenture of lease cess companyputed at the rate of three annas on a rupee of the amount of rent and royalty.

facts.text: Rent and royalty under mining lease are taxable income; amounts paid under covenant related to them also taxable.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that the rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount which is paid under a companyenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would, in our judgement, also be taxable as income.

facts.text: Excess over actual cess is income; appellant received and appropriated as entitled.

anchor.surface_text: The difference between the amounts which the appellant received and amounts for which he companyld under the terms of the lease claim reimbursement, must therefore be regarded as income with in the meaning of the Indian Income-tax Act

facts.text: Appellant did not collect as agent for government; syndicate paid contractual obligation exceeding cess.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did number purport to companylect local fund cess on behalf of the State Government number did the syndicate pay the amount to his as an agent to the Government. The syndicate merely sought to discharge what it believed was its companytractual obligation

facts.text: Liability to pay land revenue and local fund cess imposed on appellant, not lessee under Bombay Land Revenue Code.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the syndicate was an inferior holder under the appellant. ... Liability to pay land revenue and the local fund cess is imposed by the Bombay Land Revenue Code upon the appellant.

facts.text: Contention that receipts casual non-recurring abandoned before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention that this income was of a causal and number-recurring nature was abandoned before the Tribunal.

facts.text: After HC proceedings, syndicate filed suit against appellant to recover excess amounts.

anchor.surface_text: We were told at the Bar that after the proceeding for assessment in these appeals reached the High Court the Syndicate has filed a suit in the civil companyrt against the appellant to recover the amounts paid by it.

facts.text: Appeals fail and dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.

issues.text: Whether the sum of Rs. 16,309/Rs. 39,515 received by the assessee from the syndicate is income for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: Whether the sum of Rs. 16,309/Rs. 39,515 received by the assessee from the syndicate is income for the purpose of the Indian Income-tax Act, 192 ?

issues.text: If the answer to the above question is in the affirmative, whether the income-receipt is exempt under section 4(3)(vii) of the Act by reason of its being of a casual and non-recurring nature?

issues.text: Whether the appellant received and collected the sums as local fund cess on behalf of the Government of Bombay or the Local Board?

anchor.surface_text: In appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax, Baroda Range, it was maintained by the appellant that the to sums were number taxable, because they represented local fund cess companylected by him on behalf of the Government of Bombay or the Local Board, Panch Mahals,

issues.text: Whether liability to pay land revenue and local fund cess under the Bombay Land Revenue Code and Bombay Local Boards Act is imposed on the landholder or on the lessee?

anchor.surface_text: Under the Bombay Land Revenue Code, liability to pay land revenue is imposed upon the landholder.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer has exclusive jurisdiction to determine whether a particular receipt is income for the purposes of assessment?

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer is, within the limits assigned to him under the Act, a Tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction

issues.text: Whether the amounts received exceed the actual local fund cess payable by the appellant in respect of the lands?

anchor.surface_text: The local fund cess payable for the two villages demised by the appellant was, according to finding of the Tribunals, Rs. 270.45 being 3/16ths of Rs. 1,222.92 the amount of land revenue assessed on the lands. But the amounts paid by the syndicate for the two years in question companysiderably exceeded the local fund cess payable in respect of the lands.

arguments.court_reasoning: Rent and royalty taxable; amount paid under covenant directly related also taxable as income

arguments.claim: Rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty is also taxable as income

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount which is paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would, in our judgement, also be taxable as income.

arguments.claim: The difference between the amounts received by the appellant and the amounts for which he could claim reimbursement under the lease must be regarded as income under the Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: The difference between the amounts which the appellant received and amounts for which he could under the terms of the lease claim reimbursement, must therefore be regarded as income with in the meaning of the Indian Income-tax Act

anchor.surface_text: Liability to pay land revenue and the local fund cess is imposed by the Bombay Land Revenue Code upon the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer is, within the limits assigned to him under the Act, a Tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction

arguments.claim: Anything which can properly be described as income is taxable under the Act unless expressly exempted

anchor.surface_text: The observation of the Judicial Committee in Gopal Saran Narain Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax that Anything which can properly be described as income, is taxable under the Act unless expressly exempted,

arguments.claim: The Income-tax Officer can determine quantum of local fund cess payable when it arises in assessment proceedings

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the Income-tax Act which prevents the revenue authorities from determining the quantum of the amount which is payable by the appellant as local fund cess, when that question properly arises before them in the course of proceedings for assessment.

arguments.claim: The syndicate was not an inferior holder under the appellant; no provision imposes liability to pay local fund cess upon the lessee

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the syndicate was an inferior holder under the appellant. ... our attention has not been invited to any provision of the Bombay Land Revenue Code, 1879, which imposes liability to pay local fund cess upon the lessee who holds land under a lease from the landholder.

holdings.text: Rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount which is paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would also be taxable as income.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount which is paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would, in our judgement, also be taxable as income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Common ground on rent/royalty; payments under related covenant have similar quality, received and appropriated by assessee.

holdings.text: The difference between the amounts received by the appellant and amounts for which he could claim reimbursement under the lease terms must be regarded as income under the Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The difference between the amounts which the appellant received and amounts for which he could under the terms of the lease claim reimbursement, must therefore be regarded as income with in the meaning of the Indian Income-tax Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Excess over actual cess liability received and appropriated; applies inclusive definition of income.

holdings.text: The appellant did not purport to collect local fund cess on behalf of the State Government nor did the syndicate pay the amount to him as an agent to the Government.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant did not purport to collect local fund cess on behalf of the State Government nor did the syndicate pay the amount to him as an agent to the Government. The syndicate merely sought to discharge what it believed was its contractual obligation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Payments made to discharge contractual obligation under lease, not as agent; syndicate believed liable on rent/royalty base.

holdings.text: The syndicate was not an inferior holder under the appellant; liability to pay land revenue and local fund cess imposed by Bombay Land Revenue Code upon the appellant (landholder).

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to hold that the syndicate was an inferior holder under the appellant. ... Liability to pay land revenue and the local fund cess is imposed by the Bombay Land Revenue Code upon the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definitions (ss.3(13),3(14)); no provision imposes cess liability on lessee; post-abolition, landholder liable.

holdings.text: Revenue authorities can determine quantum of local fund cess payable when question arises in assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the Income-tax Act which prevents the revenue authorities from determining the quantum of the amount which is payable by the appellant as local fund cess, when that question properly arises before them in the course of proceedings for assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No bar in IT Act; necessary for assessment; addresses HC reservation on actual liability.

holdings.text: Income-tax Officer is a Tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction to determine whether a receipt is income for assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer is, within the limits assigned to him under the Act, a Tribunal of exclusive jurisdiction for the purpose of assessment of income-tax. He has under the Act to decide whether a particular receipt is income

holdings.reasoning_summary: ITO decides income without needing third parties; appealable but not prevented by potential disputes.

holdings.text: Local fund cess levied on land revenue at statutory rate; manual instructions do not modify the Act.

anchor.surface_text: This plea is based upon the complete misconception of what is stated in the Manual of Revenue Accounts, 1951. ... By the instructions it is not sought to be conveyed that local fund cess in respect of non-agricultural incomes ... is to be levied at the rate different from the rate prescribed by the statute.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Manual gives entry instructions, not substantive law; statute fixes rate on land revenue, not rent/royalty.

holdings.text: Receipts not exempt under s.4(3)(vii) as not casual and non-recurring; contention abandoned before Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The contention that this income was of a casual and non-recurring nature was abandoned before the Tribunal. It cannot be said that the receipt was produced by the chance or was accidental, fortuitous or from unforeseen sources of income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Abandoned; not chance/accidental/unforeseen; recurring under contract; even if mistake, lacks casualness.

holdings.text: Received amount retains income character in year received even if payer may later claim refund.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has received certain amount under a contract with the syndicate, and if that amount was income, the fact that the person who paid it may claim refund will not deprive it of its character of income in the year in which it was received.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tax on receipt and appropriation in assessment year; civil recovery separate.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that the rent and royalty under the mining lease are income taxable under the Act, and an amount which is paid under a covenant directly related to the payment of rent and royalty would, in our judgement, also be taxable as income.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed with companyts.
